Metering accuracy, SCADA points, alarms, remote control, data logging
Utility witness testing, acceptance sign-off, energization coordination
Core equipment testing hours (excludes L1-L3 and contingency)
Design drawings, submittals, O&M manuals, coordination studies
Installation QA, nameplate verification, grounding, clearances
Daily coordination, vendor calls, utility meetings (included in Cx Mgr/Doc Coord hours)
Core testing + overhead (excludes transformer hours pending RFI). With transformer testing, estimate ~1,100-1,300 hours base.

column1: Note: Discrepancy between bottom-up equipment hours and WBS crew allocation hours reflects:

column2: 1. Crew availability/standby time during specialist vendor testing
2. Weather delays and outdoor work restrictions (Louisiana May-July)
3. Utility coordination delays and waiting time
4. Safety requirements and work permit constraints for high voltage testing
5. Parallel activities and multi-discipline coordination inefficiencies
1. 300 MW switchyard divided into 6 blocks of 50 MW each per utility distribution architecture
2. Equipment quantities per block: 2 MV switchboards + 23 RMUs per RFP totals (12 ÷ 6 and 138 ÷ 6)
3. Main transformer quantities and utility voltage UNKNOWN - requires RFI-001.07 clarification (CRITICAL)
4. Cx Manager (1.0 FTE) shared across all 6 switchyard blocks - provides program-level oversight
5. Documentation Coordinator (0.25 FTE) shared across 6 blocks - centralized documentation support
6. 12-week duration per block assumes sequential or partially overlapping commissioning
7. Weather contingency (15%) built in for Louisiana May-July outdoor high voltage testing
8. Utility coordination and witness testing critical path items - schedule depends on utility availability
9. High voltage testing requires specialized test equipment and certified technicians
10. Switchyard must be fully commissioned and energized before any data hall commissioning can begin

column4: Requires completed utility interconnection design before L1 can start
Requires utility engineer review and approval before energization - long lead time
GC must complete installation before commissioning can begin
Louisiana May-July: hurricanes, thunderstorms, high humidity affect outdoor testing
Utility controls energization timeline - may not align with project schedule
High voltage test equipment (megger 500kV+) rental availability and lead time
Require utility-approved or certified technicians for high voltage work
Main transformer scope unclear, utility voltage unknown, equipment list incomplete

column1: Overall Risk Rating: HIGH due to critical path nature and RFI-001.07 scope ambiguity

Witness testing summary and GC test report review

Executive summary, all test results, issues log, photos, turnover documentation
Operator training on switchyard equipment and emergency procedures
Document any field changes to design for as-built drawing updates
